Posts.Title: Milestones of recovery

Posts.Content: I'd say I'm a positive outcome. You've probably seen my other comments, but the synopsis is; for 4 months after surgery, I had little stirrings down there, but not much else. I tried viagra, but it did not work, much to my disappointment. I got a pump, and started having sex 5-6 months post surgery. I got trimix and it worked great. for the next 6 months or so, my progress (without aid) was very slow, but steady. Now, at about 20 months, I have about 90% chance of a good erection without any help. I can have spontaneous sex - which works better for me in the mornings. I still keep the pills around and sometimes take a small shot. I have a good sex life.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Badger199 Are all prostatectomy's carried out robotically in USA?? Here in UK we only have 2 hospitals with that facility (that we could have been referred to anyway but miles and miles away from where we live). No, surgeons still do open procedures. In my case, I had an experienced urologist perform an open procedure. The robotic (Da Vinci) method is increasingly common, and does yield quicker recovery, but it seems like the main factor in outcomes is the experience of the surgeon, no matter which procedure is used.

Posts.Title: I am Part of the Zero Club

Posts.Content: Badger199; Maybe my experience will help. About 2 months after my (open) RP, I noticed my flow getting weaker. Not nearly as bad as you describe, but my uro warned me about this. He said scar tissue could develop and choke things off. What he did was dilate my urethra using three successively larger catheters (using a local anesthetic). It did the trick and I have excellent flow now. I think it's important to have it done soon after you start healing, otherwise the scar tissue hardens.

Posts.Content: The nerves that provide sensation are different than the ones that control erections. When someone has prostate surgery, the nerves that control erection may be removed or damaged, but it's not likely to affect the nerves that provide sensation. I would guess your situation is not comparable to prostate surgery. I had nerve-sparing surgery, and did not have good erectile function for about a year, but never lost sensation.

Posts.Title: Can your sex life really get back to normal?

Posts.Content: mickcee, I had nothing going on down there for about 3 months after my surgery. I was terrified. I had no results with Viagra or Cialis. I did have good results with the pump - so I don't see how you could not get that working. For me, it took some fiddling, which was annoying, but it got me to a satisfying place. I also had good results with Trimix injections. I'm now 14 months post-op, and getting better erections. About half the time, I can get things to work out on their own. The Viagra and Cialis are working for me. And I can go to the pump for backup if needed. What I'm saying is that I think castration is far too serious for you to consider. I have a friend in my support group that is going to get a penile prosthesis - you should at least consider that. As for me, my wife of 31 years had asked me for a divorce about 4 months prior to surgery - so no sex action there. But I have picked up a wonderful girlfriend who has helped me enormously through all of this. Hang in there.

Posts.Title: castration

Posts.Content: Fasteddie: I am a runner, and triathlete. I've done 10 marathons, 15 or so half-marathons, 3 Olympic distance triathlons, and many shorter races. Last November I had an open RRP. Ten days after the catheter was out, I stopped using pads. My doc advised against lifting, but said I could walk then run as much as I could handle. My own criteria for starting to run was whether I felt like I could handle a fall (at speed) without messing something up. I was out walking around the block (very gingerly) two days after getting out of the hospital. I gradually streched out the walks to 10km. It was seven weeks before I ran one mile. For me, the discomfort was mostly from the abdominal scar, with a little discomfort internally. I did not have much problem with incontenince on the run. A big milestone for me was getting back to a level of running that felt "normal" to me. For this, I set a goal of 10km in one hour (which was a typical pre-surgery training run for me). I managed to achieve this 3 months after surgery.

Posts.Title: 20 months of incontinence

Posts.Content: My situation sounds similar to your fella - except I'm a bit younger and had an open procedure. I had the added troubles of going through a divorce at the same time as surgery. On the other side, I began a delightful new relationship with a new partner. At 6 months, I was not responding well in the erection department, but things soon got better, very slowly. In those times, I used a pump with good success, and then started Trimix injections. Now, at almost a year and a half, I still keep viagra handy, but most of the time I don't need it. My advice - tell your partner that you're getting tips from some of us that have been through this before, and get him to experiment. Getting to orgasm without an erection is a good place to start. I think you ought to get him talking to a urologist about pills, pump, or injections. A willingness to experiment, along with some patience is what it takes. Feel free to ask me questions - in PM if you like.

Posts.Title: Longterm Girlfriend seeks advice

Posts.Content: AsksALOT, I am an atheist. Going through diagnosis/surgery/recovery without a god-belief is an interesting experience. I (and most atheists I know) deal with struggles by recognizing the advances in medical science, in sharing feelings with their close friends and family, and taking some consolation in knowing that your troubles are not designed by some supernatural force. I am not familiar with Campbell, but I took a look at some of his YouTube lecture. Frankly, I did not see anything that related to the issue of dealing with cancer. Did you have a question, or point to make?

Posts.Title: Management of Emotions for Athiests

Posts.Content: I'm interested in everybody's posts here. My deal is this - I know I'm on the positive side of all the statistics regarding diagnosis and treatment. But, I still don't think of myself as "cured". And the other word "survivor" still does not sit well with me. I think that I'm a "victim" of cancer. That's just my opinion. And, mind you, I'm having a very happy life without incontinence or ED problems. For my money, I would have to be convinced that the probability of me having cancer (after treatment) is less than or equal to any other man walking around at my age. Then I might feel "cured". But, so far, I don't think that is possible to say that is so.

Posts.Title: What comes after I have my first biopsy--scheduling question not a medical one

Posts.Content: Okay, I'll share: I'm 21 months post RRP. I have no continence problems. I usually have dry orgasms (75% of the time). If there's urine in my bladder, some might come out. If I have a full bladder, it might be a big gush. So, I usually empty out before things get started, and there's no problem. As time goes on, there seems to be less chance of urine. I do sometimes have pre-ejaculatory fluid that comes out, as others have explained. I can't predict when it will happen, but it is definitely not urine. As for the feeling, I'd say that it is harder (takes longer) to reach orgasm than the old days. Maybe that's a bonus (if you ask my girlfriend). On average, the orgasms are weaker than before, but vary up to "as good as" before. I kind of miss the sensation of the ejaculate, but it's a small thing.

Posts.Content: I found that the catheter was not as bad as I expected. I'm not saying it's any fun. It is a nuisance. But of all the troubles with surgery (I had an open procedure), it does not rank high. The worst thing for me was the itching irritation that it caused at the end of my penis - which was relieved with a little astroglide to lubricate the thing. Changing the bag, and getting around was really not much of a problem for me. I took off work, but I did go out to visit friends and go for walks with it.

Posts.Title: Catheter

Posts.Content: I have read many books and articles about PC treatment, however, I cannot say I've found a clear answer to this question: Generally speaking, will radiation treatment for PC cause infertility? From what I read the answer seems to be - maybe, and most likely it will, but not definitely. I ask because I wonder if this is a real concern for people making decisions. In particular, I'm curious if you're a fertile guy who chooses radiation. Afterward, do you still use contraception? This is not a personal issue for me (prostatectomy). But I'd like to understand it better for the people who ask me about it.

Posts.Title: Five years in the zero club

Posts.Content: HiSunshine: I can tell you what helped me decide. I am 53, and also am a marathoner. The fact that I thought I could tolerate the surgery well, and that with the surgical option, I would have a fall-back of radiation treatment is what caused me to choose surgery. Also, I have heard that the side-effects from surgery (if any) tend to get better over time was important to me. As it turned out, I had an open retropubic procedure just over a year ago. I have no troubles with incontinence. I'm still affected with erectile problems, but each month I seem to get a little better. With help from pills and shots, I have a good sex life.

Posts.Title: masturbation after surgery

Posts.Content: I'm doubting the 1/1000 figure. I looked up the size of an 18G needle (what I hear is typical) and did the math. With a prostate volume of 24 cm^3 and an avg of 2 cm of tissue in 12 cores, you have 0.55 % of the prostate. More like 1/180 rather than 1/1000. Still, a pretty small amount. This is the thing that troubles me most about the diagnosis and treatment vs. active surveillance dilemma. The biopsy is a sampling process, and I've never seen a good explanation of the probabilities.

Posts.Content: I am honored to have a sticky from a thread that I started. My best advice on dealing with ED is this: be willing to experiment. I'm coming from a relationship that ended that did include sexual problems (not related to ED) and then starting a new relationship fresh with ED as part of the package. You need to be able to try things (pumps, pills, shots) and positions and oral and time of day and everything - and be willing to have some of those things not work - then learn what does work. I had the good fortune to find a new partner willing to deal with this with a positive attitude, and I am pretty happy.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About ED

Posts.Content: I had the unfortunate experience of being diagnosed with PC just a month after my wife (of 31 years) asked me for a divorce. We had sex issues, but nothing attributable to the PC. Now, on the other side of divorce and RRP, I have been lucky enough to find a new partner, who has been great in dealing with the ED from the start of our relationship. This is just to say, in my case anyway, prostate cancer is not good for your sex life, but it is no worse than the other troubles one might have in a relationship. My sex life is better now than it ever was.

Posts.Content: I'm doubting the 1/1000 figure. I looked up the size of an 18G needle (what I hear is typical) and did the math. With a prostate volume of 24 cm^3 and an avg of 2 cm of tissue in 12 cores, you have 0.55 % of the prostate. More like 1/180 rather than 1/1000. Still, a pretty small amount. This is the thing that troubles me most about the diagnosis and treatment vs. active surveillance dilemma. The biopsy is a sampling process, and I've never seen a good explanation of the probabilities.
Posts.Signature: Diagnosed at age 52. PSA in 2000 2.2 02/24/2011 3.8 08/24/2011 5.2 Biopsy on 10/3/2011 Malignant in 1 of 8 cores. Gleason 3+3=6 11/15/2011 Open Retropubic Radical Prostatectomy Negative Margins post - op PSA: 01/15/2012 undetectable 07/15/2012 undetectible 01/10/2013 undetectable 07/16/2013 undetectable 01/21/2014 undetectable

Posts.Title: 12 core biopsy samples 1/1000 of the prostate, What does that mean

Posts.Content: I have donated blood to the Red Cross one year after surgery. Their criteria was 1 year since the last "treatment" for cancer. They did not ask anything about PSA. I'm also on the bone marrow registry, they will not take me for 5 years.

Posts.Title: Update and question about blood donation post op

Posts.Content: (In my case...)The catheter tube is attached to the upper thigh with a stick-on swivel, and a bag is attached to the mid-thigh. Boxers are good. I wore loose running pants. Sweat pants would work too.

Posts.Title: What to take to the hospital

Posts.Content: I am honored to have a sticky from a thread that I started. My best advice on dealing with ED is this: be willing to experiment. I'm coming from a relationship that ended that did include sexual problems (not related to ED) and then starting a new relationship fresh with ED as part of the package. You need to be able to try things (pumps, pills, shots) and positions and oral and time of day and everything - and be willing to have some of those things not work - then learn what does work. I had the good fortune to find a new partner willing to deal with this with a positive attitude, and I am pretty happy.
Posts.Signature: Diagnosed at age 52. PSA in 2000 2.2 02/24/2011 3.8 08/24/2011 5.2 Biopsy on 10/3/2011 Malignant in 1 of 8 cores. Gleason 3+3=6 11/15/2011 Open Retropubic Radical Prostatectomy Negative Margins post - op PSA: 01/15/2012 undetectable 07/15/2012 undetectible 01/10/2013 undetectable 07/16/2013 undetectable 01/21/2014 undetectable
Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About ED

Posts.Content: I had the unfortunate experience of being diagnosed with PC just a month after my wife (of 31 years) asked me for a divorce. We had sex issues, but nothing attributable to the PC. Now, on the other side of divorce and RRP, I have been lucky enough to find a new partner, who has been great in dealing with the ED from the start of our relationship. This is just to say, in my case anyway, prostate cancer is not good for your sex life, but it is no worse than the other troubles one might have in a relationship. My sex life is better now than it ever was.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About ED

Posts.Content: I don't post much anymore, but I still check this forum from time to time. Four years ago today I had my prostate removed, via open surgery. All of my PSA checks since then have been negative. Continence is very good. Sexual function is good, not as good as it was - but with a little help I have no problems. Life goes on...

Posts.Title: Four year anniversary.

Posts.Content: I had the unfortunate experience of being diagnosed with PC just a month after my wife (of 31 years) asked me for a divorce. We had sex issues, but nothing attributable to the PC. Now, on the other side of divorce and RRP, I have been lucky enough to find a new partner, who has been great in dealing with the ED from the start of our relationship. This is just to say, in my case anyway, prostate cancer is not good for your sex life, but it is no worse than the other troubles one might have in a relationship. My sex life is better now than it ever was.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About ED

Posts.Content: I am honored to have a sticky from a thread that I started. My best advice on dealing with ED is this: be willing to experiment. I'm coming from a relationship that ended that did include sexual problems (not related to ED) and then starting a new relationship fresh with ED as part of the package. You need to be able to try things (pumps, pills, shots) and positions and oral and time of day and everything - and be willing to have some of those things not work - then learn what does work. I had the good fortune to find a new partner willing to deal with this with a positive attitude, and I am pretty happy.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About ED

Posts.Content: I'm doubting the 1/1000 figure. I looked up the size of an 18G needle (what I hear is typical) and did the math. With a prostate volume of 24 cm^3 and an avg of 2 cm of tissue in 12 cores, you have 0.55 % of the prostate. More like 1/180 rather than 1/1000. Still, a pretty small amount. This is the thing that troubles me most about the diagnosis and treatment vs. active surveillance dilemma. The biopsy is a sampling process, and I've never seen a good explanation of the probabilities.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About ED

Posts.Content: In my opinion, the experience of the surgeon himself is more important to the outcome than whether you have Da Vinci or not. The Da Vinci is less invasive, and and on average will have a lesser recovery time, however, your result may vary. On your own with no family might tip slightly towards Da Vinci, but I would not let that be the only determining factor. After considering the options, I went with an experienced and well-recommended urologist who did only open procedures, and I am happy with the result.

Posts.Title: 14 month post - op status

Posts.Content: Well, it's been a year since my surgery, so I suppose I should give an update. I was diagnosed with PC in October 2011. At the time I was in the middle of a divorce from my wife of 31 years. I was devastated. My ex was kind enough to back off on the legal stuff 'till I got back on my feet. Somehow I got through all of that, and today I am a happy guy. My last PSA was 0.014, so I'm just keeping an eye on that with visits to the urologist twice a year. My side effects are manageable. In the continence department, I have very little trouble, only an occasional dribble when I drink alcohol, and sometimes when I start to get an erection. In the ED department, things have been slow to recover. I had some stirrings down there about 2 months post op, and it took about 6 months to get a workable erection without assistance, however, it was not reliable.. I have had success with viagra and cialis. I also have used trimix injections, and have a pump for backup. Now at 12 months, I still have those tools on hand, but am finding that I don't always need them. My sex life is pretty good. Better now with a new girlfriend than in the latter days of my marriage (pre-surgery). To those who are worried - I'd say that RP is not good for your sex life, but in my case, finding a new partner with a great attitude has overcome the bad side effects. Also, my urologist has given me good straight-talk advice and treatment. So, there you go. I'm still keeping an eye on things, and I do get concerned if I see the PSA creep up, but I'm here, and life goes on...

Posts.Content: My experience has been that I've had a few "geysers", but as time goes on, it got to be less and less. Now, I just empty out before things get started and don't notice any urine. It's not an issue for me anymore. I don't have any incontinence problems, however, I can say this: when I have the first hint of arousal down there, I sometimes let go with a couple drops.

Posts.Title: Incontinence while ejaculating.

Posts.Content: On the first try, you doc should be cautious, to see what your reaction is. In my case, I got a barely workable erection for about 20 min. Later, with a bigger dose, things worked better. So, don't get your hopes up too much. It takes some time, but it's worth it.
